It is characterized by its silvery-blue needles and tall, slender form, often reaching heights of up to 60 meters. The tree produces cones that are typically 5 to 8 centimeters long, containing winged seeds that are dispersed by wind. Its bark is thin and reddish-brown, becoming more fissured with age. The Pacific silver fir is adapted to moist, temperate climates and is often found in mountainous regions.
